issues.text: whether in so far as Jogendra Chaudhary is concerned, common intention to commit murder had been established

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel, however, said that in so far as Jogendra Chaudhary is concerned, common intention to commit murder had not been established. The existence of common intention has always to be inferred from facts. Here it has been established that all the three appellants came together.

issues.text: whether Nepali Master has been sufficiently identified given identification at the test identification parade by one witness only and that the other persons did not turn up for identification

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of Nepali Master the learned counsel contended that he has been identified at the test identification parade by one witness only and that the other persons did not turn up for identification and, therefore, it is not legally permissible to base the identification by only one person.

issues.text: whether the admission contained in Ext. 6 as to the motive is admissible under s. 21 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: This being so, the admission contained in Ext. 6 as to the motive is clearly admissible under s. 21 of the Evidence Act. The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that Ext. 6 afforded corroboration to the evidence of P. W. 7 Srilal Chaudhary and P. W. 9 Dukhi Mahto.

issues.text: whether Ex. 6 is hit by s.162 of the Criminal Procedure Code because it was received by the Sub-Inspector during the course of the investigation

anchor.surface_text: It is then contended that Ex. 6 is hit by s.162 of the Criminal Procedure Code because it was received by the Sub- Inspector during the course of the investigation. Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code only bars proof of statements made to an investigating officer during the course of investigation.

arguments.claim: common intention to commit murder had not been established in so far as Jogendra Chaudhary is concerned

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel, however, said that in so far as Jogendra Chaudhary is concerned, common intention to commit murder had not been established. The existence of common intention has always to be inferred from facts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d, some of them were in the dalan and some in the adjacent room when the appellants came near there and one of them cried out Darogaji. Their evidence

arguments.court_reasoning: Inferred from all three appellants coming together armed with guns, prior motive/grievance against deceased for reporting movements and aiding arrest, accompanying throughout, and statements made at incident like reference to Motia and sarcasm about military.

arguments.claim: evidence cannot be reappraised in special leave appeals when accepted by Sessions Judge and High Court

anchor.surface_text: Their evidence has been accepted as true and adequate not only by the learned Sessions Judge who had an opportunity to see and hear the witnesses depose but also by the High Court. Their evidence cannot be reappraised in their appeals by special leave.

arguments.claim: Nepali Master identified only by one witness at test identification parade and others did not turn up, so not legally permissible to base conviction on it

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of Nepali Master the learned counsel contended that he has been identified at the test identification parade by one witness only and that the other persons did not turn up for identification and, therefore, it is not legally permissible to base the identification by only one person.

arguments.court_reasoning: Even single witness sufficient if court regards as truthful after seeing/hearing; here identified by two witnesses PW7 and PW9.

arguments.claim: evidence of single witness can sustain conviction if court regards witness as truthful

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to say that even the evidence of a single witness can sustain the conviction of an accused person if the court which saw and heard him depose regards him as a witness of truth.

arguments.claim: test identification parade held long after arrest, so evidence of identification witnesses not believable

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court and is also contended before us that as the test identification was held long time after his arrest, the evidence of these two witnesses could not be believed.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.162 bars only statements made to police officer in course of investigation; requires ascribable to enquiry; anonymous letter de hors the investigation, not a statement to officer during enquiry.

arguments.claim: s.162 CrPC bars only statements made to investigating officer during course of investigation, not all during period; must be ascribable to enquiry

anchor.surface_text: Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code only bars proof of statements made to an investigating officer during the course of investigation. Section 162 does not say that every statement made during the period of investigation is barred from being proved in evidence.
All the appellants denied having participated in the incident. The defence is that a false case has been concocted by the police.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: against the three appellants on March 15, 1959. It is the prosecution case that the appellants are veteran criminals and the chaukidars used to repor

arguments.court_reasoning: Eyewitness evidence naming appellants accepted by trial court and HC; motive established; handwriting links Ext.6 and 3 to Nepali.

arguments.claim: Ext.6 corroborates PW7 and PW9 evidence

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that Ext. 6 afforded corroboration to the evidence of P. W. 7 Srilal Chaudhary and P. W. 9 Dukhi Mahto.

arguments.claim: common intention inferred from circumstances: coming together armed, motive, accompanying, statements

anchor.surface_text: The existence of common intention has always to be inferred from facts. Here it has been established that all the three appellants came together. Two of them, Ramchandra and Jogendra had guns, with them.

holdings.text: Their evidence cannot be reappraised in their appeals by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Their evidence has been accepted as true and adequate not only by the learned Sessions Judge who had an opportunity to see and hear the witnesses depose but also by the High Court. Their evidence cannot be reapp

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts observed witnesses and accepted evidence; special leave jurisdiction limited to not reappreciating facts.

holdings.text: there can be no doubt that common intention to commit murder was established not only with respect to Jogendra but also with respect to Nepali Master who was all along with them.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, there can be no doubt that common intention to commit murder was established not only with respect to Jogendra but also with respect to Nepali Master who was all along with them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inferred from appellants coming together armed with guns, prior motive and grievance against deceased, accompanying throughout incident, and statements made at the time referring to Motia and sarcasm about military.

holdings.text: even the evidence of a single witness can sustain the conviction of an accused person if the court which saw and heard him depose regards him as a witness of truth.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to say that even the evidence of a single witness can sustain the conviction of an accused person if the court which saw and heard him depose regards him as a witness of truth.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established legal standard applied; here Nepali Master identified by two witnesses PW7 and PW9, believed by lower courts.

holdings.text: Nepali Master was identified not by one witness only but by two witnesses P. W. 7 Srilal Choudhary and P. W. 9 Dukhi Mahto.

anchor.surface_text: However, in this case, Nepali Master was identified not by one witness only but by two witnesses  P. W. 7  Srilal Choudhary and  P. W. 9  Dukhi Mahto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application to facts overcoming objection to single identification at parade.

holdings.text: the admission contained in Ext. 6 as to the motive is clearly admissible under s. 21 of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Handwriting expert opinion links Ext.6 to Nepali Master, making it his admission relevant under s.21.

holdings.text: Ext. 6 afforded corroboration to the evidence of P. W. 7 Srilal Chaudhary and P. W. 9 Dukhi Mahto.

anchor.surface_text: This being so, the admission contained in Ext. 6 as to the motive is clearly admissible under s. 21 of the Evidence Act. The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that Ext. 6 afforded corroboration to the evidence of  P. W. 7  Srilal Chaudhary and  P. W. 9 Dukhi Mahto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission provides motive corroboration to identification witnesses.

holdings.text: the document in question is not hit by s. 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: A communication like Ext. 6 will not fall within the ambit of such statements. In this view we hold that the document in question is not hit by s. 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code and the High Court was right in admitting it in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Anonymous letter not a statement made to investigating officer in course of investigation; de hors the enquiry; s.162 requires statement ascribable to police enquiry.

holdings.text: Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code only bars proof of statements made to an investigating officer during the course of investigation.

anchor.surface_text: It is then contended that Ex. 6 is hit by s.162 of the Criminal Procedure Code because it was received by the Sub- Inspector during the course of the investigation. Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code only bars proof of statements made to an investigating officer during the course of investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes period of investigation from statements in course thereof; must be to police officer and linked to enquiry.
